At that hotel that shall remain unnamed, they provide transportation services from their hotel to the Tsuen Wan MTR station with two large tour buses, with buses every 30 minutes or so. Here at Royal View, there is only one 29 seat shuttle bus that goes to Tsuen Wan MTR, and this shuttle bus doesn't come around until an hour later, so if one misses the bus, they would either have to take a long walk out to take the minibus or wait an hour for the next shuttle bus. Also, the staff was at first very reluctant in forming a line for guests to line up in to board the shuttle buses, resulting in obvious chaos. On a final note, the broadband internet service here is horrible and often kicks you off the system, a problem that rarely occurs in other hotels. On the bright side, the view really is very nice, the air conditioning is amazing and the swimming pool is pretty nice to dip in in the evening. Overall my stay at the Royal View hotel was horrific compared to that of other hotels I have stayed in over the years as a constant visitor to Hong Kong.

Reviews.Title: “Fun to stay in a brand new hotel!”
Reviews.Author: contentedcow
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for two nights 22nd and 23rd May. The hotel was not fully open and there was still some work going on, but it wasn't noisy or intrusive. We got the impression that we were acting as guinea-pigs for staff training and that there were very few other guests. All staff that we interacted with were eager to please and spoke a little English. Our first impression on arriving at the hotel was that we'd made a big mistake in booking it because it is built right underneath one of the bridges connecting the New Territories to the other islands and also there are several busy roads all around. However, once inside the hotel we were not aware of this at all, and I am really sensitive to noise. The whole ambiance is of peacefulness and elegance. The rooms were average sized, even quite generous by Hong Kong standards, and very comfortable. The beds were firm, but not hard and had good quality bedding. I have not stayed in a brand new hotel before and it was very nice to think that we were probably the first people to sleep in them! The view from the window was of the sea, with a variety of boats constantly passing by and was quite mesmeric! The TV only has a couple of non-Chinese channels, which didn't bother us other than our daughter being unable to catch American Idol! There is a small kitchen area with tea/coffee making facilities, a sink and a fridge, but no microwave or plates or anything. Plenty of cupboard space, but I don't know what for! The bathrooms are nice, although not very big. It took us a while to realise that to get hot water in there we had to use a switch on the wall outside! The shower has a regular removable shower head and also an overhead rain shower one, which was great. You can only use one at a time though. One minor point, the tap over the sink was fixed so close to the edge of the basin that it was difficult not to splash water everywhere when washing your hands. Obviously everything was brand new, so very clean and in excellent condition. The health club and pool area were not open, but we had a look round and they are very nice, with some good fitness equipment. The gym looks out over the pool, which is in a garden setting and would be very relaxing to sit by or swim in. We ate two meals in the hotel's Cafe Lido and would recommend both. The first day we had the buffet lunch, which was under 100 HKD each and included a main course chosen from a menu of about half a dozen items, plus the soup, salad and dessert buffet. All the food was beautifully presented and well prepared, with freshly baked bread rolls and was good value, although the drinks were expensive - my coke cost half as much again as the meal - but there was water provided and continually refilled, so another time I would stick with that. The next day we tried the set breakfast in the same cafe, including fresh fruit, a cooked main course, toast and jams/marmalades, plus tea or coffee, which they kept filled up. I think it was around 70HKD, so not particularly cheap, but it was good and there was plenty of it. There isn't anything else around the hotel, so you are stuck with the hotel food unless you want to go the 5 minutes or so into Tsuen Wan. There are 2 free hotel shuttle buses which go on separate, circular routes at scheduled times. One goes to Tsuen Wan MTR and the Tsing Yi Airport Express stations, the other into Kowloon. Again, they were brand new. There wasn't much room for luggage, so you'd be better off getting a taxi if you had much luggage, also they are not that frequent and we needed to be at the airport before the first scheduled bus. the hotel desk ordered us a taxi to be there for 6:30 am and it was waiting for us. It was about 200 HKD, plus luggage charges of another 50, to the airport. We chose this hotel because of the early flight and it was much cheaper than the airport hotels. However, it isn't in a particularly convenient position and we spent quite a bit of time on the subway in and out of Hong Kong, which wasn't a problem for us. It's not very close to the airport though - I would guess about 30 minutes door to door and about the same into Central. I think this would be a good hotel to say in if you want to spend time relaxing at the hotel and don't mind some travelling to get to the main tourist parts of Hong Kong and we would definitely go back, at least while it is cheap and new.

HotelInfo.Name: Royal View Hotel
HotelInfo.Address: No.353 Castle Peak Road, Tsuen Wan, Hong Kong, China
